content.description:
Many works of literature depict complex friendships that contribute both to a character’s growth and to challenges the character faces.

Either from your own reading or from the list below, choose a work of fiction in which a complex friendship contributes both to a character’s growth and to challenges the character faces. Then, in a well-written essay, analyze how that friendship contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. Do not merely summarize the plot.

In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation.

Provide evidence to support your line of reasoning.

Explain how the evidence supports your line of reasoning.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your argument.

Absalom, Absalom!

Adventures of Huckleberry Finn

American Buffalo

Angels in America, Parts I and II

The Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man

Beloved

Cat’s Eye

The Color Purple

The Good Soldier

Great Expectations

The Great Gatsby

Henry IV, Part I

The House of Mirth

The Importance of Being Earnest

The Joy Luck Club

The Kite Runner

Life of Pi

“Master Harold” . . . and the boys

The Merchant of Venice

Of Mice and Men

On the Road

Othello

Our Mutual Friend

A Passage to India

Passing

The Piano Lesson

The Poisonwood Bible

A Prayer for Owen Meany

Pride and Prejudice

The Remains of the Day

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead

The Secret History

The Sense of an Ending

A Separate Peace

Song of Solomon

Sula

The Sun Also Rises

The Turn of the Screw

Vanity Fair

White Noise

The Wings of the Dove

The Women of Brewster Place
content.question: In a well-written essay, analyze how that friendship contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole. Do not merely summarize the plot.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Describe how textual details reveal nuances and complexities in characters' relationships with one another.
